title: How to Make Peach Cobbler Using Cake Mix

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C).
Drain the juice from one of the cans of peaches.
steps.description: Open up both cans of sliced peaches. Leave the juice in one of the cans, and drain the juice from the other. Set the drained juice aside for later.

steps.headline: Spread the peaches across the bottom of a baking pan.
steps.description: Get out a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02-centimeter) baking pan. Dump both cans of peaches into the pan. Use a spoon or spatula to spread them evenly across the bottom. You don't have to grease the inside of the pan since you won't be taking the cobbler out of it. You can grease it if you want to, however, to make clean up easier.

steps.headline: Pour the dry cake mix over the peaches.
steps.description: Do not add the other ingredients listed on the box. Simply open up the box and pour the dry mix evenly over the peaches. If you have to, use a spoon to spread the mix evenly across the peaches. Do not stir.

steps.headline: Cut the butter, then add it to the pan.
steps.description: Slice the butter into 18 pieces, then scatter it evenly across the cake mix and the peaches. Once again, do not stir.

steps.headline: Add some flavor with peach juice and ground cinnamon.
steps.description: Pour the reserved peach juice from before over the cake mix. Add a dash of cinnamon over the top for extra flavor.

steps.headline: Bake the cobbler for 30 to 35 minutes.
steps.description: As the cobbler bakes, the melting butter and peach juice will mix with the dry cake mix and produce a crumbly crust. The cobbler is ready when it turns a golden brown color.

steps.headline: Serve the cobbler.
steps.description: Leave the cobbler in the pan. Use a spatula to cut it and serve it. It will be very crumbly, so don't worry if it falls apart. You can serve it as-is, or with some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

steps.headline: Place the canned peaches into a slow cooker.
steps.description: Open up the cans, and dump everything (including the syrup) into a 4 to 6-quart (4 to 6-liter) slow cooker. Use a spoon or spatula to spread the peaches evenly across the bottom, if needed.

steps.headline: Pour the dry cake mix on top.
steps.description: Do not prepare the cake mix with any of the ingredients listen on the box. Just open the box up and pour the cake mix over the peaches.

steps.headline: Cut the butter and add it to the slow cooker.
steps.description: Use a knife to cut the butter into 18 or so slices. Spread the slices across the cake mix, making sure to distribute the pieces evenly.

steps.headline: Add some flavor with a dash of cinnamon, if desired.
steps.description: You can leave the cinnamon out if you want to, but peaches and cinnamon are a delightful combination. How much you add is up to you, but a shake or two would be delicious.

steps.headline: Cook the cobbler until it is done.
steps.description: If you are in a hurry, cook it on HIGH for 2 to 3 hours. If you have a little more time, cook the cobbler on LOW for about 4 hours. Cover the slow cooker with a dish towel. This will seal the lid and help trap the heat.

steps.headline: Let the cobbler cool before serving it.
steps.description: Serve the cobbler straight from the slow cooker with a serving spoon. Eat it as-is, or top it off with some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

steps.headline: Light the briquettes and let them burn until they turn gray.
steps.description: You can do this in a chimney starter or a campfire. It will take about 15 minutes for the briquettes to burn, so you can save time by preparing the rest of the cobbler in the meantime.

steps.headline: Grease the inside of the Dutch oven.
steps.description: You can use cooking oil, butter, or shortening. To make clean up even easier, you can line the bottom go the oven with tin foil first.

steps.headline: Empty the cans of peaches into the Dutch oven.
steps.description: Use a rubber spatula or a spoon to spread them across the bottom of the oven in a thick, even layer.

steps.headline: Pour the cake mix on top.
steps.description: Do not add any of the other ingredient listed on the box or stir anything. Simply open up the box, and dump the mix evenly on top of the peaches.

steps.headline: Cut the butter into pats and add it on top.
steps.description: Slice the butter into 5 or 6 pieces, then scatter them evenly across the cake mix. Once again, leave everything as-is and do not stir.

steps.headline: Add some flavor with ground cinnamon.
steps.description: For extra flavor and texture, you could even add some brown sugar.

steps.headline: Place charcoal briquettes on the top and bottom of the oven.
steps.description: Use tongs to arrange the briquettes in a circle a little smaller than the Dutch on a heat-safe surface. Place the Dutch oven on top, then use the tong to load more briquette on top, just inside the lip. Place a few more briquettes across the lid. Wear thick gloves to protect your hands.

steps.headline: Cook cobbler for about 38 minutes.
steps.description: Use the tong to lift the lid every so often and check on the cobbler. It is done when the top of the cobbler is cakey and no longer dry or flour-y. If the cobbler is not done, let it continue cooking; check back on it every 5 minutes or so.

steps.headline: Serve the cobbler.
steps.description: Let the cobbler cool off a little first, then serve it using a serving scoop. For extra flavor, add some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

text: Using an Oven Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C).  Drain the juice from one of the cans of peaches. Open up both cans of sliced peaches. Leave the juice in one of the cans, and drain the juice from the other. Set the drained juice aside for later. Spread the peaches across the bottom of a baking pan. Get out a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02-centimeter) baking pan. Dump both cans of peaches into the pan. Use a spoon or spatula to spread them evenly across the bottom. You don't have to grease the inside of the pan since you won't be taking the cobbler out of it. You can grease it if you want to, however, to make clean up easier. Pour the dry cake mix over the peaches. Do not add the other ingredients listed on the box. Simply open up the box and pour the dry mix evenly over the peaches. If you have to, use a spoon to spread the mix evenly across the peaches. Do not stir. Cut the butter, then add it to the pan. Slice the butter into 18 pieces, then scatter it evenly across the cake mix and the peaches. Once again, do not stir. Add some flavor with peach juice and ground cinnamon. Pour the reserved peach juice from before over the cake mix. Add a dash of cinnamon over the top for extra flavor. Bake the cobbler for 30 to 35 minutes. As the cobbler bakes, the melting butter and peach juice will mix with the dry cake mix and produce a crumbly crust. The cobbler is ready when it turns a golden brown color. Serve the cobbler. Leave the cobbler in the pan. Use a spatula to cut it and serve it. It will be very crumbly, so don't worry if it falls apart. You can serve it as-is, or with some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream. Using a Slow Cooker Place the canned peaches into a slow cooker. Open up the cans, and dump everything (including the syrup) into a 4 to 6-quart (4 to 6-liter) slow cooker. Use a spoon or spatula to spread the peaches evenly across the bottom, if needed. Pour the dry cake mix on top. Do not prepare the cake mix with any of the ingredients listen on the box. Just open the box up and pour the cake mix over the peaches. Cut the butter and add it to the slow cooker. Use a knife to cut the butter into 18 or so slices. Spread the slices across the cake mix, making sure to distribute the pieces evenly. Add some flavor with a dash of cinnamon, if desired. You can leave the cinnamon out if you want to, but peaches and cinnamon are a delightful combination. How much you add is up to you, but a shake or two would be delicious. Cook the cobbler until it is done. If you are in a hurry, cook it on HIGH for 2 to 3 hours. If you have a little more time, cook the cobbler on LOW for about 4 hours. Cover the slow cooker with a dish towel. This will seal the lid and help trap the heat. Let the cobbler cool before serving it. Serve the cobbler straight from the slow cooker with a serving spoon. Eat it as-is, or top it off with some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream. Using a Dutch Oven Light the briquettes and let them burn until they turn gray. You can do this in a chimney starter or a campfire. It will take about 15 minutes for the briquettes to burn, so you can save time by preparing the rest of the cobbler in the meantime. Grease the inside of the Dutch oven. You can use cooking oil, butter, or shortening. To make clean up even easier, you can line the bottom go the oven with tin foil first. Empty the cans of peaches into the Dutch oven. Use a rubber spatula or a spoon to spread them across the bottom of the oven in a thick, even layer. Pour the cake mix on top. Do not add any of the other ingredient listed on the box or stir anything. Simply open up the box, and dump the mix evenly on top of the peaches. Cut the butter into pats and add it on top. Slice the butter into 5 or 6 pieces, then scatter them evenly across the cake mix. Once again, leave everything as-is and do not stir. Add some flavor with ground cinnamon. For extra flavor and texture, you could even add some brown sugar. Place charcoal briquettes on the top and bottom of the oven. Use tongs to arrange the briquettes in a circle a little smaller than the Dutch on a heat-safe surface. Place the Dutch oven on top, then use the tong to load more briquette on top, just inside the lip. Place a few more briquettes across the lid. Wear thick gloves to protect your hands. Cook cobbler for about 38 minutes. Use the tong to lift the lid every so often and check on the cobbler. It is done when the top of the cobbler is cakey and no longer dry or flour-y. If the cobbler is not done, let it continue cooking; check back on it every 5 minutes or so. Serve the cobbler. Let the cobbler cool off a little first, then serve it using a serving scoop. For extra flavor, add some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.
